All right, just to give everyone a quick introduction to what covenant is it's a dotnet command and control framework
Really the aims of the project are one to highlight the attacks or surface of dotnet
That was really kind of the motivation to create it in the first place
but also just to make offensive dotnet tradecraft easier for us red team operators and to serve as like a
collaborative c2 platform for red teamers
So it's multi-user many people can interact and work together on a project
some of the key features in covenant is
There's a lot of versatility features
So for instance, the server side is written in dotnet core which makes it cross platform so you can run the server on
Windows Linux or Mac OS so if you only have like one Windows VM available to you
You can run the server on Windows and test out with implants on the same system
It's multi-user. So you'll see me and Justin interacting with the same covenant server at the same time
Which makes it easier to collaborate and I think it has a pretty intuitive web interface
Which makes it a little easier to get started using the project
There's also built-in implants for both dotnet framework and dotnet core
The dotnet core is a little bit newer but the dotnet framework one has been around for a while
There's a large library of built-in tasks these primarily utilize open-source projects like sharps point and ghostpack and
It's really customizable. So as we'll be showing in the labs there you can create custom tasks for yourself
Create c2 profiles to really change what the network traffic looks like on the wire and you can create your your own implants
It'll do handy things for you like track indicators that you can give to your blue team after the operation
and track credentials that you've captured with something like Mimi caps and
Finally, there is a peer-to-peer c2 system, which you'll be able to see in the labs as well
Brief description of the high-level architecture
So we have the covenant server really the way that works is it just stands up a GUI that operators will
All interact with over their own web browser. It's gonna store stuff in a SQLite database on the back end
It also stands up an API that you can interact with for like extendability
purposes and actually listeners use that API
under the hood and
finally, you'll have grunts calling back to your listener and those can be
Communicate with each other over a peer-to-peer protocol
So I'm seeing I am monitoring for questions in the chat I do see one
question about sock support
That's definitely on the to-do list, but currently there's no sock support
So when would you actually use covenant a few scenarios that it might make sense to you
I know there's a lot of c2 frameworks out there nowadays. You kind of have your pick of the litter
So some reasons you might use covenant is one
If you want more control over your post exploitation tasks in covenant
There's no forced process injection, which I know in some frameworks can be the case
So that's kind of helpful from either an invasion
Perspective if you are up against some EDR product that's closely monitoring that
Secondly, if you want a pure dotnet framework implant
That can go all the way down to dotnet 3.5
It's not gonna ever use PowerShell unless you explicitly request it
I know PowerShell used to be kind of the fan favorite, but now can give visibility problems
If you want to use dotnet core implants
I'm not aware of any other c2 that uses dotnet core implants yet
But that's one unique feature in covenant
If you want really granular control over the c2 structure like using profiles
Or if you just want to change implants write your own or track indicators easily

So say we did something like this,
we have just one initial egress implant

You can see we have a whole mesh

The state of this graph is maintained by Covenant

So the server knows where all of the implants are located

And when it wants to send a message,
let's say to implant G in this case,
say you type in shell, who am I for that grunt?
What's gonna happen is Covenant's going to basically
recursively encrypt a message along that path.
So it's gonna take the message, encrypt it with G's key,
take that chunk, encrypt it with B's key,
take that chunk, encrypt it with A's key,
and then that's going to be decrypted
as it goes across the wire.
So implant will send that message to A,
which can decrypt it because it was encrypted with A's key.
Same thing with B, and then G will finally unravel
the shell, who am I message,
and be able to execute that and return results for you.

from the grunt to the C2 server
is traditionally like a JSON blob
